data.title: Nicolas Maduro files motion to dismiss US criminal case, citing due process violations - filing
Sysco Keeps Quarterly Dividend at $0.54 per Share, Payable April 24 to Holders of Record on April 2
Democrat questions use of USAID funds for Trump budget chief's security
data.description:
WASHINGTON, Feb 26 (Reuters) - A Democratic lawmaker is questioning the use of funds from the former U.S. foreign aid agency to pay for White House budget chief Russell Vought's security, calling it "a gross abuse of power" and a deviation from their congressionally approved purpose.

Reuters reported on February 13 that the Office of Management and Budget has allocated more than $15 million from U.S. Agency for International Development operating expenses to cover the cost of Vought's protection by the U.S. Marshals Service this year.

Referring to the Reuters report, Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi wrote in a letter to Vought on Wednesday that using the funds for his security detail "deviates sharply from Congress's intent and undermines the agency's core purpose."

"The misuse of funds is fundamentally wrong and a gross abuse of power," Krishnamoorthi said.

Vought's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Trump last year ordered USAID's closure, claiming without offering proof that it was rife with corruption. Thousands of personnel and contractors were fired and programs closed, throwing U.S.-funded global aid programs into turmoil.

A skeleton crew is closing out USAID's remaining contracts and is due to shut the 64-year-old agency for good by September.

Krishnamoorthi asked Vought to disclose details of the USAID funds being used to pay for his security, including their "original congressional intent" and whether the budget chief had notified Congress that they had been reallocated.

Krishnamoorthi also asked whether other White House funding sources were considered and who authorized the USAID funds to be used to cover the costs of his protection. 

(Reporting by Jonathan Landay and Douglas Gillison; Editing by Don Durfee, Rod Nickel)

Utilities Fall, but Not by Much, on Defensive Demand -- Utilities Roundup
data.description:
Shares of power producers fell, but not by as much as the broad market, as traders sought out defensive sectors.

Oil lobbyists are urging Trump officials to hold off on attacks on wind farms off the U.S. coast, risking derailing congressional efforts to speed up permits for energy projects.

Pollution from U.S. power plants rose last year, a rare uptick in an otherwise long-term downward trend, partly because of more coal being burned to generate electricity.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1748ET

data.title: Apple seeks dismissal of fraud lawsuit over Siri AI, Epic injunction
Communications Services Tick Up After Mixed Earnings -- Communications Services Roundup
data.description:
Communications-services ticked up amid mixed earnings.

Warner Bros. Discovery logged lower revenue in its latest quarter, driven by declines across each of its segments, as it remains in the middle of a high-stakes bidding war between Netflix and Paramount Skydance.

Canadian carrier Quebecor's fourth quarter profit rose after adding more mobile users to its network, supporting higher revenue growth.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1747ET

data.title: Walmart agrees to pay $100 million to settle deceptive earnings charges, FTC says
Tech Down as Nvidia Weighs -- Tech Roundup
data.description:
Shares of technology companies fell as traders remained skittish about the artificial-intelligence boom.

Nvidia shares fell by more than 5% despite the AI chip maker's forecast of revenue growth above Wall Street's lofty expectations. Nvidia's shares are now in negative territory for the year to date, as optimism about the widespread adoption of AI turns to skepticism about the sustainability of AI companies' capital expenditure.

EBay will lay off about 6.5% of its global workforce, or roughly 800 employees, as part of an effort to cut costs and restructure the business.

Sam Altman startup Tools for Humanity is seeking to sell technology that will verify whether transactions are conducted by humans or machines.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1747ET

data.title: Nutrien Brief: Announcing TSX Approval for Its Renewed Share Repurchase Program; Representing Up to 5% of Its Issued and Outstanding Common Shares
Financials Up Amid Deal Activity -- Financials Roundup
data.description:
Shares of banks and other financial institutions rose amid deal activity.

Victory Capital submitted a bid to acquire Janus Henderson that would be significantly higher than the $7.4 billion offered in December by Nelson Peltz's Trian Fund Management and venture firm General Catalyst.

Federal Reserve governor Stephen Miran said he thinks the Fed needs to cut interest rates by about a percentage point this year in a Fox Business interview Thursday. Miran also said he has not seen anything particularly worrying in private-credit reports.

Shares of Blue Owl, whose efforts to forestall withdrawals from one fund sparked the latest round of worries about the non-bank lending niche, lost ground.

The average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage was 5.98% this week, the lowest since September 2022 and a slight decline from last week, Freddie Mac said. The recent dip below the psychologically significant 6% level has spurred refinancing activity.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1746ET

data.title: Consumer Cos Flat as Mortgage Rates Drop Below 6% -- Consumer Roundup
data.description:
Consumer companies were more or less flat as mortgage rates crossed a psychologically significant barrier.

The 30-year mortgage rate fell below 6% for the first time since 2022, in a development that could stir demand for homes and refinancing.

Hormel Foods fell after the maker of Skippy peanut butter, Planters nuts and Spam warned elevated commodity costs may continue to pressure margins over the coming year.

Shares of J.M. Smucker surged after the jam-maker struck an agreement with activist investor Elliott Investment Management and appointed two new members to its board.

Walmart agreed to pay $100 million to settle Federal Trade Commission claims that the retailer misled delivery drivers about the pay and tips they could earn.

Krispy Kreme said profit margins rose during the fourth quarter as the doughnut chain's turnaround gained momentum, though revenue fell after it exited underperforming locations.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1746ET

data.title: CoreWeave CFO: We expect to exit 2026 with annualized run rate revenue of $17 bln to $19 bln
Health Care Down Amid Mixed Earnings -- Health Care Roundup
data.description:
Health-care companies slipped amid mixed earnings.

Shares of Novavax soared after the vaccine developer swung to an unexpected profit in the fourth quarter and exceeded its expense-reduction goals.

Shares of MannKind fell after the biopharmaceutical company posted an unexpected loss in the fourth quarter.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1745ET

data.title: CoreWeave CFO says company expects 2026 adjusted operating income of $900 mln to $1.1 bln
Energy Up With Oil Futures -- Energy Roundup
data.description:
Shares of energy companies rose alongside oil futures amid mounting risk of a U.S.-Iranian war.

The U.S. brought tough demands to a crucial round of nuclear talks with Iran and sent more jets and warships to the region Thursday, raising the pressure on Tehran as negotiators work to cut a deal that could head off a U.S. attack.

In one sign that Iran is preempting the impact of a war on its oil sector, Iranian oil flows through the Straits of Hormuz chokepoint have spiked in the last fortnight and the amount loaded onto storage tankers or en route to market has hit record levels.


Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 1743ET

data.title: OpenAI outlines steps to boost safety measures in response to Canada school shooting
data.description:
TORONTO, Feb 26 (Reuters) - OpenAI said on Thursday that it will set up a direct point of contact with Canadian law enforcement and improve detection of repeat policy violators, among steps to boost its safety protocols in the wake of a recent school shooting in Canada.

The ChatGPT maker detailed the steps in a letter to Canada's minister in charge of artificial intelligence. 

(Reporting by Ryan Patrick Jones, Bhargav Acharya and Ismail Shakil; Editing by Caroline Stauffer )
